text:
CHRIS CUOMO: Thousands
of Americans at this hour

are descending on
Washington, DC,

for what's expected to be
a massive women's march.

- And here on Capitol Hill,
hundreds of thousands of women

are marching today in
cities across the country.

- Over 600 of these
marches in all,

more than 2 million people
expected to turn out.
- In the spirit of democracy--

- --and honoring the
champions of human rights--

- --dignity and justice
who have come before us.

- We join in diversity
to show our presence
in numbers too great to ignore.

- The Women's March
on Washington--

- --will send a bold message
to our new government--

- --on their first
day in office--

- --and to the world
that women's rights
are human rights.

- We stand together,
recognizing that defending

the most marginalized amongst
us is defending all of us.

- We support the
advocacy and resistance

movements that
reflect our multiple
and intersecting identities.

- We call on all defenders
of human rights to join us.

- This march is the first
step towards unifying
our communities--

- --grounded in
new relationships--

- --to create change from
the grassroots level up.

- We will not rest until
women have parity and equity--

- --at all levels of
leadership in society.

- We work peacefully,
while recognizing there

is no true peace without
justice and equality for all.
- Hear our voice.
- It's happening.

We just had a really
successful call

with maybe 100 women of color
from different walks of life.

As long as we keep on thinking
about that-- even the program,

I was like, OK, we
need indigenous folks.

It just can't be
black and white.
We don't live in a binary world.

Trump went after Mexicans,
Muslims, undocumented people.
- What are we doing?

VANESSA WRUBLE: We're going
to do a very brief sort of go

around of who's who and what
we're all doing since we're

finally in the same
place, and most of us

have never met
each other before.

- My background is I left a
large corporate executive job

to spend the last 570
days working for Hillary
Clinton at Hillary for America.
So I was also a little bummed.
[laughter]

- My background is
in international law.

And right now I'm
a public defender,
and I also do immigrant defense.

So people who are immigrants
and who are getting

deported, we use
international law
to prevent their deportation.

JANAYE INGRAM: So obviously,
after the election, I was--
I was a lot of things.
I was pissed.
I was angry.
I was like all over the place.

I've organized a lot
of marches and rallies,

some as big as we
think this one will be,

although I think
it could go bigger.

BOB BLAND: My name's
Bob Bland, and I

am one of the national
co-chairs, along with Carmen
and Tamika and Linda.

And I was also
one of the day one
people at the very beginning.

I think one of the most
transformative things

about this march and the
movement that is rising from it

is that people who are
not used to getting out

of their comfort zones
are now finally saying,
OK, enough is enough.

I had a Nasty Women
T-shirt go viral right
after the third debate.
It was like instant community.

We had over 3,000 people who
had bought shirts or totes.

On election night, we were
all so completely devastated.

This was time to get out
from behind our computers
and actually do something.

That was really how
it snowballed all day,

was just women from
all over the country

who had never met each other,
coming together online.

None of us knew how big
it was going to get.

- What Bob did, in
terms of organizing

these masses of people who
were inspired to come march,
is incredible.

Not to mention that
in the middle of this
is she gave birth.
BOB BLAND: No to the movement.
[laughter]

VANESSA WRUBLE: No,
not to the movement.

I mean, literally to
the movement and--
- To a human baby.

VANESSA WRUBLE:
--to a human baby.
BOB BLAND: Tamika was there too.

TAMIKA MALLORY: I was in the
hospital with the contractions.

And then we only knew
each other for two days.
[laughter]

BOB BLAND: We were having a
straight-up business meeting.
[laughter]

TAMIKA MALLORY: So
I am Tamika Mallory.
I am a civil rights activist.

I've been working in
the space of activism
for almost 20 years of my life.

My parents were two of Reverend
Al Sharpton's first members

when he started
over 26 years ago.

So I was literally the
three-year-old girl
in the protests.

Organizing, for me, in
this march, in this moment,

is as much about my survival,
my family's survival,
my friends' survival.
My son's father was murdered.
And my son was two years old.

In order to ensure his
safety and protection,

I know that I must get up every
day concerned about the issues

as it relates to particularly
black men in this country.

I come as an angry
black woman at all times
of my life, every day.

People who are sort of
waking up post-Trump,

it's completely fine
because I feel like
everyone has a point of entry--
everyone.

So now that I see it, how can
this country look like this?

But the truth is it has
always looked like this.

LINDA SARSOUR: My
name is Linda Sarsour,

and I came to you today from
Brooklyn, New York, which
is where I was born and raised.

I'm a Palestinian
Muslim American.

I'm a daughter of
Palestinian immigrants

who came here from
Palestine in the 1970s

from living under
military occupation.

I have been serving
in my own community

as a civil rights activist
since the ashes of 9/11,

as someone who comes from a
very targeted community by
all levels of law enforcement.

And I come to this
space, also, like Tamika,

from a community that has
basically suffered in silence.

And none of our fellow
Americans have stood up for us.

It's a big morale booster
for people in my community

to see someone who looks like
me be in a leadership position

and to be in a
public demonstration

against this
administration that says,

actually, this
time around, we're
not going to suffer in silence.

There are actually people
who know what's going on,

and we're standing here
together in these mass numbers

telling you that we're
not going to back down,

and we're not going to allow
you to target our Muslim sisters

and brothers, our black
sisters and brothers,

our Native American, our
Latino, our undocumented.

Women have always been
leaders in this country.

Just because we don't have
the first woman president,

doesn't mean that
there is no women
leadership in this country.

Maybe if we allow the women to
lead once and for all in this

visible way, maybe we will
bring justice to our committees
in a way that we haven't.
CARMEN PEREZ: I'm Carmen Perez.

And so I've been in the
world of criminal justice,

movement building, civil
rights, human rights
for the past 20 years.

We're really angry at the
fact that Trump came out
with this very racist rhetoric.

But that's just really the
fabric of America, right?

And so how do we attack the
forces of evil and not people
doing evil?

Because this is
really beyond Trump.

This is not about Democrats
versus Republicans.

This is about building
our communities back up.
- We're all in the headquarters.
We're all working 24/7.

Now it's 17 days
before the march,

and we're all working
tirelessly on logistics.

LINDA SARSOUR:
This administration

cannot ignore hundreds
of thousands of people.

This is going to be the
largest mass mobilization

that any new administration has
ever seen on their first day.

TAMIKA MALLORY: We
all want big numbers.

But as we get bigger, we need
more port-a-potties to make

sure that people are
comfortable and that we
have the right accommodations.

And security has clearly
been a major concern.

LINDA SARSOUR: Insurance can
range anywhere from $30,000

to $40,000 for the
amount of people
that we will have at the march.

So I really welcome folks
with whatever size donations

you have, whether it be small
donations on Crowdrise-- $50,
We are not yet at our goal.

My experience of
organizing this march

has been when we
were continuously

asked questions about
where the permit was--
permit, permit, permit, permit.

And no one wanted to have a
deep conversation about why
we were marching, who are we.

I wondered, did anyone
ever ask a group

of men who were organizing
a march the same questions
that they were asking us?

TAMIKA MALLORY: Women
are carrying the weight
of the community on our backs.

And so we're going
to Washington talking

about the entire community,
bringing the issues

of the entire family
with us, and asking men
and children to join us there.

LINDA SARSOUR:
The intentionality

of saying it's the Women's
March on Washington

is that this is a
woman-led movement.

And you have to be
comfortable in your own skin

as a man in this country to say,
yes, I will be led by women.

We're also intentional
about what kind of women

are leading this Women's
March on Washington.

TAMIKA MALLORY: History is
going to record this thing,
one way or the other.
- Mm-hm.
That's right.

TAMIKA MALLORY: And
it will say in 2017,

there was another
white woman march.

There were some black
folks sprinkled there,

but the black women still
did not feel that they
should be a part of it.
- That it was their place.

TAMIKA MALLORY: And that
can't happened to me, right?
Because I might as well go home.

CARMEN PEREZ: We're
on the fifth week,

and we're just beginning to
bring on indigenous women

from five different
reservations.

I feel like the team
that we have is dynamic.

And I'm just trying
to figure out

what are people doing in case
we could fill some of the gaps.

TAMIKA MALLORY: There cannot be
a convening in this nation that

seeks to address the issues of
women where women of color are

not sitting in the front seat,
leading the conversation,

because we come from the
most impacted and the most
marginalized communities.

LINDA SARSOUR: What
we're doing here

is we are creating
another opportunity

to talk about what are the
issues that impact women.

Yes, pay equity
impacts all women.
But guess what?

Guess who gets paid
less than white women?
Women of color.

We can't have a
conversation about feminism

that doesn't include
race, that doesn't include

socioeconomic status, that
doesn't include immigration

status, that doesn't
include respecting

people's religious rights
and religious freedom
in this country.

And maybe this march is a way
for us to put that out there.

I'm just going to
throw it out there.

BOB BLAND: I think what stops
white women from acknowledging

their privilege
too often is fear,

is the fear of acknowledging
that we've had a leg up
and that we have to do the work.

The march itself is a
platform for conversations

that, at least from my
perspective, were not being had
previously.

And my perspective is one of
somebody who was not previously
an activist and organizer.

And so thank you so much to
Tamika and Linda and Carmen
for joining as leaders.

CARMEN PEREZ: OK,
we'll see you here.
OK, all right, bye.

- I can't believe we
filled this room today!
[cheering]

LINDA SARSOUR: And women,
you may have heard,

I'm one of four national
co-chairs for the Women's
March on Washington.
[cheering]

I will not respect
an administration

full of Islamophobes
that have called

the beautiful religion that
I follow a malignant cancer.
[applause]

If we are going to stand up
to xenophobia, to racism,

to Islamophobia, to homophobia,
if we are going to say,

hands off our health care, hands
off our reproductive rights,

hands off our undocumented
sisters and brothers,

then we need to say that
right here in Bay Ridge.

My approach to movement
building has always
been about intersectionality.

When people see a
light-skinned Palestinian girl

talking about
Black Lives Matter,
they look at me like I'm crazy.

A third of my
community's black too.

Do we care just about
reproductive rights?

Like if you're a Mexican woman
that's about to get deported

to Mexico, how important
are your reproductive rights
at this moment?

Being able to not prioritize
what women should care about,

but believing that we
live intersectional lives.

A politician sits
in the ivory office

somewhere on Capitol Hill,
when I can sit in the streets.
I can sit in a coffee shop.
I can sit in a community center.
I can sit in a mosque.
I can sit in a church.

I can touch people directly who
are impacted by the very issues
that I fight for everyday.

I want to give a
special shout out--

I don't know if she's here-- to
Megan Abaludo, a mom who heard

about the Women's March on
Washington, and she said,
I want to do something.

So she organized,
and she's organizing

Bay Ridge to go to the
Women's March on Washington.

It didn't require an
elected official or someone
in a high-level position.

It took a woman with convictions
and a passion and outrage

to say, I'm taking
my people, and we're
going down to Washington, DC.
[cheering]

- We have to decide the
actual front of the line,

and then we have to decide
who those 150 people are,

because those people are going
to be transported to the front
of the march by a bus.

LINDA SARSOUR:
There's some people

that have to be at the
front of the line, right?
So let's just do the have-to.

So there'll be 50
speakers, for sure,
the national team, for sure.
[whistle]
- Thank you, everyone.

We're asking organizers to
arrive beginning at 3:00 AM.

- Say it one more
time so everyone--
- Everyone.

You also have tear-down
for the inauguration.

So that's going to
be simultaneous--
building up, tearing down.
- How symbolic.
- Oh, yeah, exactly.
So 10:00 to 1:00 is the program.

We'll get into
that a little bit.

At 1:15, I have no idea how many
people are going to be here.

We, right now-- we've
communicated our growing
numbers to the city agencies.
They know about them.

There's not a lot
of real estate.

Even we don't march, but we have
bodies along that whole route,
that plan has never changed.

And we have gotten
that accomplished.

- If we are unable to march
because we have so many people,

it's amazing, it's
incredible, we'll
make that call in that moment.
But what do we tell people?

- So we should-- well, we'll
have to think a little bit more

in these next few
hours, because tomorrow
will be here in a few hours.
We'll have to think about that.
- Why can't we just march?

We might not be able
to organize it the way

we want to organized
it, but how do we
just stop people from marching?

- We don't necessarily
stop people from marching.
This is important.

This is not an opportunity
for civil disobedience.
That is not what this is.

- Today, if you
weren't tracking,

there were riots
that have raised
tensions of law enforcement.

So just to kind of
keep that in mind.
- This is Noelle.

She is the director of
operations for global.
She's our Vanessa.

And she is going
to announce what
is happening in this moment.

- You guys, it is
already January 21st
in some parts of the world.

And New Zealand is starting
to march right now.
[cheering]

LINDA SARSOUR: So
what I tell people

all the time is that don't
be offended when people are

raising their voices against
injustice in the United
States of America.
This is why we live here.

This is why we live in the
land of freedom and democracy.

If anything, those who
are raising their voices

are engaging in
freedom and democracy.

And I tell people all
the time, dissent is
the highest form of patriotism.

TAMIKA MALLORY:
It's going to roll
better if I do it that way.
We will not remember.

We will-- well, we will remember
not the words of our enemies,
but the silence of our friends.
- Tamika.
TAMIKA MALLORY: You like it?

So in this moment, what I
see as being something that

is extremely powerful
is opportunity,
but it is only opportunity.

Because until January
22nd comes and we

see people continue to do
the work, it means nothing.

That feeling, take
it back with you

to wherever it is that
you came from today.
[cheering]

BOB BLAND: Ultimately, I
feel like this is profoundly

benefited me to go
through this experience,

and I look forward to
sharing it with my children.

I look for it to the beginning
of a lifelong learning.

If we can activate and
mobilize hundreds of thousands

of people who previously would
have just been behind a screen,

then that might
make the difference.
[cheering]

- And I'd like to
introduce my hero,
feminist icon, Gloria Steinem.
[cheering]

GLORIA STEINEM: You
should see yourself.
It's like an ocean.
- Did you see that?
- No, what happened?
- Look!
Look!
- Oh, my god.

- This is history
in the making here.

CARMEN PEREZ: My
name is Carmen Perez.

I stand here as a Chicana
Mexican-American woman.

As a family member of
incarcerated and undocumented
people.

We deserve to live in a
country that is free--

free from fear, discrimination,
free from being told
what we can do with our bodies.

We're fighting for the
right to be fully present
and to be our whole selves.
